awd_titl_txt: Workshop: Hazards and Disaster Researchers Meeting: Improving Post-Disaster Rapid Reconnaissance Research; Broomfield, Colorado; July 11-12, 2018
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant provides funding for a special NSF RAPID grant focused workshop on July 11-12, 2018, that immediately follows the Natural Hazards and Disasters Research Meeting being held in Broomfield, Colorado.  As the United States has experienced more frequent and intense disasters that have affected larger numbers of people, the hazards and disasters research community has mobilized in response. Following each disaster, large numbers of core as well as situational researchers from locally-affected areas and across the nation, many with NSF RAPID grant funding, launch new studies to understand the impacts of these events on both the affected population and the built environment, to explore the root causes of the disasters, and to trace long-term recovery trajectories among population groups and across communities. This special workshop provides a forum to take stock of what the community has learned from past disaster reconnaissance research and to develop best practices for future disaster investigations.  The workshop is open to all members of the hazards and disasters research community and will convene engineers, social scientists, and public health researchers who received NSF RAPID grants in 2017 as well as those who have ongoing hazard and disaster research projects. The funds will be used principally to support travel costs for NSF RAPID awardees making presentations at the workshop. This workshop will contribute significantly to the NSF mission of promoting the progress of science in our understanding of hazards and advancing the national health and prosperity by using this understanding to reduce damage from future events.

This work will improve rapid reconnaissance research. The specific objectives are to: 1) identify salient research needs based on the experiences of RAPID grantees, leaders of disaster research coordination networks and researchers with ongoing investigations, 2) integrate new and emerging hazards and disaster researchers into the existing coordination networks through information sharing activities; and 3) generate improved research coordination, data collection, and data sharing capabilities by combining the experiences of this diverse group of emerging and established hazards and disaster researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award supported a meeting organized around the theme of Improving Rapid Reconnaissance Research: Identifying Research Needs, Coordinating Investigators, and Improving Data Collection and Sharing. The meeting was held July 11-12, 2018, in Broomfield, Colorado. It brought together 202 hazards and disaster researchers from a range of disciplines in the social and behavioral sciences, engineering, the humanities, and public health and medicine. About 23 percent of attendees were undergraduate or graduate students and the remainder included researchers who work at academic institutions or in government agencies, non-profit organizations, or the private sector. Participants came from across the United States as well as from China, Hong Kong, Italy, Japan, Korea, New Zealand, Singapore, Taiwan, and the United Kingdom.

The major goal of this award was to advance rapid reconnaissance research in the diverse multi- and interdisciplinary hazards and disaster field through hosting a Researchers Meeting for NSF RAPID recipients and other researchers engaged in rapid response research. A total of 58 NSF-funded principal investigators were invited to prepare and submit research abstracts highlighting current projects and significant results. In addition, hazards and disaster researchers without NSF funding support were encouraged to submit their research for presentation. These researchers—including both the NSF-funded investigators as well as those who responded to the open call for participation—were asked to respond in writing to one of the following four prompts meant to advance research in the rapid reconnaissance space:

(1) What challenges or opportunities have you identified in terms of conducting rapid reconnaissance research?

(2) What has your research revealed regarding team formation, rapid reconnaissance research coordination, or interdisciplinary collaboration?

(3) Has your research contributed to innovative data collection strategies? If so, please elaborate.

(4) How can data sharing and archiving capabilities be enhanced to ensure the greatest scientific impact?

The Researchers Meeting focused on sharing the results from recent research projects and convening discussions organized around opportunities and challenges, approaches, guidance, and data sharing for rapid reconnaissance research. The inclusion of recent NSF RAPID award recipients was fundamental to the success of this meeting, as was the involvement of those who have ongoing hazards- and disaster-related research projects. In addition, the meeting was further enhanced by the active participation of NSF program directors; research leaders from federal mission agencies including the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Federal Emergency Management Agency, National Institute of Standards and Technology, and U.S. Geological Survey; principal investigators of several of the NSF-funded Natural Hazards Engineering Research Infrastructure (NHERI) facilities; leaders of diversity and inclusion projects for hazards mitigation; and the principal investigators of the NSF-funded extreme events research and reconnaissance (EERs) networks.

The 2018 NSF-funded Researchers Meeting featured 11 plenary presentations and 67 concurrent paper presentations, as well as several networking events. When asked in the post-evaluation survey, 94% of respondents agreed or strongly agreed that the Researchers Meeting sessions explored innovative approaches for hazards and disaster research, while nearly 96% agreed or strongly agreed that the meeting addressed the unique opportunities and challenges of hazards and disaster research.         

The abstracts for all of the research presentations (https://hazards.colorado.edu/workshop/2018/abstract/index/researchers-meeting) as well as the responses to the four guiding prompts for the meeting (https://hazards.colorado.edu/workshop/2018/researchers-meeting/four-prompts) are posted online and are freely available to the public. The 2018 Researchers meeting website (https://hazards.colorado.edu/workshop/2018/researchers-meeting/overview) has received 10,262 page views (including 6,460 unique views) of the associated pages including the theme statement, call for papers, schedule, abstracts, and other materials.

As the number of disasters and their impact continues to increase, and as the hazards and disaster field continues to grow and more investigators launch post-disaster investigations, there is a pressing need to ensure that researchers are coordinating with one another, collaborating when possible, sharing data and data collection strategies, and adhering to the highest ethical standards. This NSF-supported Researchers Meeting was dedicated to responding to these needs and to ultimately improving the science of rapid reconnaissance research. The knowledge produced as part of this meeting has informed the development of subsequent training materials and research coordination and data collection strategies now pursued through the NSF-funded CONVERGE facility, which is headquartered at the Natural Hazards Center at the University of Colorado Boulder. In addition, the success of the 2018 meeting strengthened existing networks for collaboration and catalyzed several new convergence-oriented research efforts in the field.
